name: Chronic Total Occlusion Crossing Techniques
description: Specialized endovascular techniques for recanalizing chronically occluded arterial segments. Includes true lumen crossing (intraluminal) and intentional subintimal approaches. Success depends on lesion characteristics and operator expertise.

code.name: Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty of chronic total occlusion

cap_morphology.tapered: Gradual narrowing into occlusion - easier crossing

cto_characteristics.length: Longer occlusions have lower success rates

intraluminal_true_lumen.description: Wire navigates through original vessel lumen
intraluminal_true_lumen.technique: Soft wire, support catheter, controlled probing

subintimal_crossing.description: Wire creates channel between intima and media

pros_cons.advantages: High success rate in long lesions
pros_cons.disadvantages: Excludes collaterals, may limit future options

bolia_technique.original: Intentional subintimal dissection with loop wire

perforation.subintimal: Risk of rupture when leaving subintimal space

complications.embolization: Risk to distal bed or collaterals
complications.contrast_nephropathy: Long cases with high contrast use

outcomes.patency: Lower than de novo lesions, may require surveillance

clinical_pearls: Tapered cap = easier crossing; blunt/flush cap = more challenging
Subintimal crossing is intentional and controlled - not a complication
Reentry devices (Outback, Pioneer) are key for subintimal approach
Dual access (antegrade + retrograde) increases success rates
learning_objectives: Describe CTO lesion characteristics that predict crossing difficulty
Compare intraluminal versus subintimal crossing techniques
Explain the role of reentry devices in subintimal angioplasty

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
